newsitem.title: USA: Refugee group demands U.S. Rwanda envoy's recall.
newsitem.headline: Refugee group demands U.S. Rwanda envoy's recall.

text.p: An American group that speaks for refugees demanded the recall of the U.S. ambassador to Rwanda on Thursday, accusing him of playing down the scale of the refugee crisis in Zaire.

The Washington-based Refugees International quoted the ambassador, Robert Gribbin, as telling the British Broadcasting Corporation that most of the hundreds of thousands of Rwandan refugees in Zaire who wanted to return home had now done so.
Rwandans still in Zaire "appear to be in the tens to twenties of thousands rather than in vast numbers," the envoy was quoted as saying.

"Ambassador Gribbin is downplaying the seriousness of the refugee crisis in Zaire just ahead of a key military planning meeting in Stuttgart (Germany) tomorrow," said Lionel Rosenblatt, president of Refugees International.
"His statement leads us to wonder who actually speaks for the U.S. government on this issue."
Refugees International, which calls itself a humanitarian advocacy organisation, said in a statement it was demanding Gribbin's "immediate recall."
The Stuttgart meeting will discuss options for an international intervention force to go to Zaire, but is not expected to take any decisions.

The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees originally estimated there were around 1.1 million Rwandan refugees in Zaire, most of them Hutus who fled Rwanda after a civil war there in 1994. Up to 600,000 of them have returned home in recent days.

State Department spokesman Glyn Davies said there were conflicting reports on numbers. He said there could be up to 500,000 refugees still in Zaire but the picture was complicated by the presence of Burundian refugees and displaced Zairians.
